title: Trump says he's trying to 'reduce size of government' — but he's really not
content:
When a TV news program raised concerns in August about President Trump 's slow pace of hiring top officials in federal agencies , Trump tweeted his reply : `` We are not looking to fill all of those positions . Do n't need many of them — reduce size of government . ”
But Trump is not actually reducing the size of government .
The few thousand jobs Trump has not filled are a drop in the bucket for a federal workforce that stood at about 2.8 million in August , more or less unchanged since December . The federal workforce is now back to 2013 levels after dipping to about 2.7 million in 2014 .
And if you include state and local workers — some of whom are paid for by federal government block grants — government employment nationwide has been at a seven-year high since last September , hovering about 22.3 million .
Despite a short-term hiring freeze at the start of his administration , Trump has not imposed major workforce reductions for one obvious reason : Congress has not yet passed his budget , so the government is still running under the last budget approved by former president Barack Obama .
But a Trump budget will not likely cut government employment either , despite significant cuts to several federal agencies outlined in the budget the president proposed in May .
`` The president is n't looking to specifically cut the number of employees within the federal government , ” said John Czwartacki , spokesman for the White House Office of Management and Budget . “ In fact , in some instances such as the Department of Defense and ( veterans ) healthcare , he 's looking to expand the workforce . ”
Instead of focusing on raw numbers , Trump ’ s goal “ is to eliminate elements of bad government , making it more efficient , effective , and accountable at meeting its proper and appropriate functions , ” Czwartacki said .
Trump 's initial budget request included nearly $ 500 billion in new defense spending , $ 200 billion in infrastructure spending and a new program for paid parental leave . All of those increases would boost the government workforce .
Federal employment hasn ’ t really changed much in decades , said Paul Light , New York University professor of public service . In the 1950s , Congress set a cap on government employment , and while that cap has since been rescinded , “ the notion that the federal workforce should hover at or about 2 million ( not including the postal service ) was pretty much established , ” Light said . “ And we ’ ve held to that . ”
“ Republican and Democratic administrations get pounded when there is a slight increase — lets say 50,000 feds are added to the payroll — but in the grand scheme of things , it ’ s a rounding error , ” Light says .
There have been some ups and downs of a few hundred thousand workers . For example , federal employment spiked to nearly 3.5 million for a few months in 2010 as the government hired hundreds of thousands of short-term workers for the decennial census . And after 2001 , the federal government got a bit bigger with the creation of the Department of Homeland Security and the pursuit of two major wars .
But over the long haul , the numbers are remarkably stable . In January 2002 , there were about 2.75 million federal employees , according to data maintained by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis , about 50,000 fewer than August of this year .
Light also argues that federal employment is really just the tip of the iceberg because the federal government spends billions of dollars each year hiring contractors , who do not count as government employees . In a paper he will be releasing in early October , Light contends that counting contractors and people working under federal grants , the total federal workforce is about 7.3 million people . “ There are about 2.6 hidden , off-budget employees for every fed . ”
These are the people who are most at risk in any budget cuts , said Erica Groshen , the former Commissioner of the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics
“ The cuts might be a little more heavily weighted toward contractor jobs than career civil service jobs , partly because agencies want to preserve the human capital that they have developed , ” Groshen said . “ You have employees who know your programs , so when you need to expand temporarily or bring on some technical skill that you don ’ t have in-house , you would bring on a contractor , but when the budgets are tight you are more likely to cut your contracting expenses . ”
Federal employment rules also make it hard to downsize . To make significant cuts in the federal workforce , “ they need to have a reason to actually lay any people off , ” like a major budget cut , Groshen said . “ To have a ‘ reduction in force ’ you have to have some reason for it , ” she said . Short of that , “ any reduction at this point is probably largely through attrition . ”
Even if Trump were to make major cuts in federal employment , “ there are about 7-8 times as many state and local employees as there are federal level , so what is happening at the state and local level is going to swamp what is happening at the federal level , ” said Bill Dupor , assistant vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis .
As state economies have emerged from recession over the past few years , states again have revenue to spend on their workforce , Dupor said , and the level of government employment has returned to pre-recession levels . “ It 's not that the level of government has blown up over the past five years , it has just gotten back to where it was , ” he said .
And it will likely stay there a while . “ Barring another recession that would send spending down , I do n't think there is going to be major change , ” Dupor said .
